org.opends.server.tools.upgrade

Class FileManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.opends.server.tools.upgrade.FileManager

  • public class FileManager
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility class for use by applications containing methods for managing file system files. This class handles application notifications for interesting events.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  FileManager.DeletionPolicy
      Describes the approach taken to deleting a file or directory.

    • Method Detail

      • deleteRecursively

        public static void deleteRecursively(java.io.File file)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Deletes everything below the specified file.
        Parameters:
        file - the path to be deleted.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if something goes wrong.

      • copy

        public static java.io.File copy(java.io.File objectFile,
                java.io.File destDir,
                boolean overwrite)
                         throws java.io.IOException
        Copies everything below the specified file.
        Parameters:
        objectFile - the file to be copied.
        destDir - the directory to copy the file to
        overwrite - overwrite destination files.
        Returns:
        File representing the destination
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if something goes wrong.

      • rename

        public static void rename(java.io.File fileToRename,
          java.io.File target)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Renames the source file to the target file. If the target file exists it is first deleted. The rename and delete operation return values are checked for success and if unsuccessful, this method throws an exception.
        Parameters:
        fileToRename - The file to rename.
        target - The file to which fileToRename will be moved.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If a problem occurs while attempting to rename the file. On the Windows platform, this typically indicates that the file is in use by this or another application.
